instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green - Amber - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.59V
threads.message:
Hello,

Got this Macbook Air. Board is clean. When connected I get green and orange led, fan doesn't spin. SMC looks ok.

I am suspecting <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> but before removing anything i want to make sure.

<CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> Pin1 = Diode mode = 0 
<CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> Pin2 = Diode mode = 0 

U 7501
23 = 0.0 V
22 = 0.00 V
12 = 3.4V
13 = 2.64 V
29 = 0.33 V
21 = 3.4 V

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> NON = 0,59

<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> 2 = 0.59V

<RESISTOR>R1405</RESISTOR> 1 = 0.59V <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
<RESISTOR>R1405</RESISTOR> 2 = 1.45V <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>
<RESISTOR>R1410</RESISTOR> 1 & 2 = 0.59V <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 
<RESISTOR>R1452</RESISTOR> 1 = 0.59V
<RESISTOR>R1452</RESISTOR> 2 = 0.59V <SIGNAL>PCIE_WAKE_L</SIGNAL>
<CAPACITOR>C1845</CAPACITOR> = 0.59V <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>




thanks
Sam

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green - Amber - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.59V
threads.message:
"<CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> Pin2 = Diode mode = 0"
Any reason to check ground to ground???

"I am suspecting <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR>"
There are many more components connected to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, apart of <CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR>.

Post exact ohm resistance to ground.
Compare with the resistance on the big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green - Amber - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.59V
threads.message:
right... GND to GND...

so Diode Mode, red probe on GND
<CAPACITOR>C7500</CAPACITOR> PIN1 = ohm resistance 0.000 ( i know you won't like it : )

L7139 = .112
L7520 = .112

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green - Amber - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.59V
threads.message:
No other big coils visible on the board?
The VCORE ones are first to check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green - Amber - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.59V
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green - Amber - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.59V
threads.message:
Being pure short to ground, is very likely a filter cap.
However, always discard first a short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and a big coil.

Should be safe to use voltage injection method now.
1V is probably good enough to find the culprit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green - Amber - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.59V
threads.message:
Thanks.
It was <CAPACITOR>C7376</CAPACITOR>.
Fan still not spin after replacement. I'll have to keep searching.

<RESISTOR>R7006</RESISTOR> = 1.04V now at  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.message: Should be bad now; just check it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green - Amber - <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =  0.59V
threads.message: I don't know how you know that but you were right (y)(y). I've changed it and now fan spin ! Thank you very much
